Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Ventral and Dorsal Surgical Approaches for Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy

Trial_Design.evidence: In this multicenter randomised controlled trial, 250 patients with CSM were recruited from 11 sites over 18 months.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either ventral surgery or dorsal surgery (laminectomy/fusion or laminoplasty).

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare the outcomes of ventral versus dorsal surgical approaches for CSM.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Short Form-36 Physical Component Summary (PCS) score at one-year follow-up.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of the 250 participants, 159 were randomised: 80 to ventral and 79 to dorsal surgery.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean difference in SF-36 PCS scores between the ventral and dorsal groups was [insert effect size], 95% CI [insert CI]; p = [insert p-value].

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in [insert number] of the ventral group and [insert number] of the dorsal group, with [insert severity].
